thread.title: Topeka's two downtowns combine for one big day
thread.title_full: Topeka's two downtowns combine for one big day

author: Bill Blankenship
title: Topeka's two downtowns combine for one big day
text:
Topeka's two downtowns combine for one big day People fill Kansas Ave. north and south of river on days of civic celebrations Posted: October 17, 2015 - 5:08pm Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL New Orleans-based Bonerama's trombonists, from left, Matt Mullins, Greg Hicks and Craig Klein, headline the inaugural Capital City Jazz & Food Truck Festival, which was staged Oct. 10 on a stage just west of the intersection of 9th and South Kansas Avenue. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL Their faces decorated for the Mexican holiday of Dia de Los Muertos (Day of the Dead), Grupo Folklorico Zochipitzahualtl dancers entertain an audience seated on North Kansas Avenue in the NOTO Arts District at the Dia de los Muertos Street Fair on Oct. 10. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL Hundreds in lawn chairs await the start of the Capital City Jazz and Food Truck Festival as hundreds more shop for their food Oct. 10 in the 800 and 900 blocks of South Kansas Avenue. Organizers estimated attendance at 5,000. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL Mexican-born singer Alexia Romero performs with dancers from Grupo Folklorico Xochipitzahuatl on Oct. 10 at the fourth annual Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) Street Fair in the NOTO Arts District. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL Topeka Mayor Larry Wolgast welcomes those attending the inaugural Capital City Jazz and Food Truck Festival which was staged Oct. 10 in downtown Topeka where Wolgast said more events will be offered when renovations are complete on South Kansas Avenue. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL One of the marionettes from the Stone Lion Puppet Theatre, from Kansas City, Mo., dances Oct. 10 for those attending the fourth annual Dia de los Muertos ( Day of the Dead) Street Fair in the NOTO Arts District. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL Mark Mullins, a co-founder of the trombone trio-led New Orleans band Bonerama performs in the shadow of the Kansas Statehouse at the inaugural Capital City Jazz and Food Truck Festival on Oct. 10 in downtown Topeka. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL In an area set aside for them to get creative, children created art Oct. 10 at the fourth annual Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) Street Fair in the 800 and 900 blocks of North Kansas Avenue in the NOTO Arts District. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL The Augmented Fifths, a local jazz band arranged by saxophonist Craig Treinen, director of jazz studies at Washburn University, performs Oct. 10 in the block just east of the Kansas Statehouse at the inaugural Capital City Jazz and Food Truck Festival. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL Nancy Marston, of Aunt Nancy's Face Art, of Berryton), decorates the face of 4-year-old Myra Lindbloom, of North Topeka, who was at the fourth annual Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) Street Fair with her grandmother Mary Osborn. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL From left, trombonists Greg Hicks, Mark Mullins and Craig Klein, who lead the New Orleans brass band Bonerama, headline the inaugural Capital City Jazz & Food Truck Festival which was staged Oct. 10 in downtown Topeka. Back | Next BILL BLANKENSHIP/THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL Vendors sell the skeleton figurines and skulls traditional to the Mexican holiday of Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) at the fourth annual street fair staged by the Tonantzin Society in the NOTO Arts District. ONLINE 
To see more photos from the inaugural Capital City Jazz and Food Truck Festival in downtown Topeka and the fourth annual Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) Street Fair in the NOTO Arts District, which were both staged Oct. 10, go to Spotted.CJOnline.com. By Bill Blankenship bill.blankenship@cjonline.com 
Festivalgoers filled the streets of both of Topeka’s downtowns Oct. 10 as they partied in the afternoon at the fourth annual Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) Street Fair on North Kansas Avenue and spent the evening dining and jamming to music at the inaugural Capital City Jazz and Food Truck Festival on South Kansas Avenue. 
While the NOTO Arts District has remained a popular destination for street festivals, such as its portion of the monthly citywide First Friday Artwalks, two years of traffic-diverting street reconstruction and sidewalk renovation have rerouted parades and limited some activities on South Kansas Avenue in downtown Topeka. 
However, with the remodeling closer to completion, Topeka Mayor Larry Wolgast told the estimated 5,000 gathered to hear the New Orleans trombone trio-led, rock-oriented band Bonerama to expect more fair and festivals in downtown Topeka on a monthly, sometimes weekly, basis. Vince Frye, president and chief executive officer of Downtown Topeka Inc., agreed, saying the renovated South Kansas Avenue, with its pocket parks, will make downtown a go-to site for Topekans and visitors to the city. 
While organizers of the Dia de los Muertos Street Fair feared the Capital City Jazz and Food Truck Festival might dampen attendance, turnout was larger than expected at both festivals. Many attended both events. That was evidenced by those people who were bobbing their heads to Bonerama's music with their faces still decorated for Day of the Dead. 
The two festivals also had to compete against home football games at Washburn University, Kansas State University and the University of Kansas. And they weren’t the only events going on Saturday, but those other activities also drew well, such as Saints Peter and Paul Antiochian Orthodox Christian Church’s 10th annual Greek Food Festival, which sold all the food it prepared for the annual fundraiser. 
Bill Blankenship can be reached at (785) 295-1284 or bill.blankenship@cjonline.com .
